item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: W.N.B.A. Star Returns to Russian Court After Pleading Guilty
item.description: Brittney Griner has become one of the world’s most famous prisoners after more than 140 days in custody. The U.S. accused Russia of war crimes, citing hundreds of thousands of Ukrainian deportations.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A girl playing with her dog near a school that was hit by shelling in Bakhmut on Wednesdsay.

item.title: On Mideast Trip, Biden Reassures Israelis on Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: After arriving for a four-day trip to Israel and Saudi Arabia, the president said the U.S. would use force if need be to prevent Iran from developing a bomb. He also paid his respects at a Holocaust memorial.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden arriving in Jerusalem on Wednesday. He said it was “an honor to once again stand with friends and visit the independent Jewish state of Israel.”

item.title: Sri Lanka in Chaos as President Flees and Protesters Object to Interim Leader
item.description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa fled, protesters angered by an economic meltdown overran the interim leader’s offices, and it was unclear who, if anyone, was in charge.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall, Skandha Gunasekara and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters stormed the prime minister’s offices in Colombo, Sri Lanka, after the president fled the country on Wednesday.

item.title: Who’s the Oldest of Them All?
item.description: Two towns in Sardinia battle for the distinction of having the longest-living residents. One has the imprimatur of Guinness World Records.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adolfo Melis, 99, is part of a family in Perdasdefogu, in Sardinia, that earned the Guinness World Record for the highest combined age of more than 800 years for nine living siblings.

item.title: Pope Names Three Women to Office That Helps Select Bishops
item.description: The three women will serve five-year terms in the Vatican office that vets candidates, enhancing the role of women in the church’s operations.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: A Vatican courtyard. One expert said the appointment of three women to a previously all-male committee would resonate throughout the church.

item.title: Sunak Leads in U.K. Voting to Replace Prime Minister Boris Johnson
item.description: The former chancellor of the Exchequer led a pack of candidates after the first round, while an obscure trade minister surprised in second place.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak leaving the prime minister’s residence in May, when he was chancellor of the Exchequer.

item.title: Police Arrest Owner of South African Tavern Where 21 Teenagers Died
item.description: Two employees were also arrested. Investigators have yet to say what killed the teenagers, who were found one June night collapsed in an overcrowded bar.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Forensic teams at the Enyobeni Tavern in East London, where 21 teenagers died.

item.title: Bad Planning and Errors Led to Champions League Chaos, Report Says
item.description: A French Senate inquiry faulted the authorities for blaming large crowds of supporters instead of owning up to their failures, after violence and confusion marred a final near Paris.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Many Liverpool fans were unable to enter the Stade de France in time for the scheduled kickoff of the Champions League final in May, prompting officials to delay the start of the match.

item.title: Prime minister assumes role of acting president at President Rajapaksa’s request.
item.media:description: Sri Lankan prime minister Ranil Wickremesinghe at his office in Colombo, Sri Lanka, in June.

item.title: Israel Downs Iran Drones With Arab Help, Signaling Growing Ties
item.description: The destruction of Iranian drones last year was an early example of a new regional military project that President Biden is trying to shore up during his Middle East visit.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Iranian Army Office, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Drones in an underground base in Iran. Over the past decade, Iran and its proxies in Yemen, Lebanon, Syria and Iraq have increasingly used the weapons to attack Israel and others.

item.title: After Ukraine-Russia Meeting, U.N. Sees ‘a Ray of Hope’ to Free Grain
item.description: Negotiators did not reach a deal to allow grain to flow from blockaded Ukrainian ports and ease a global food crisis, but the U.N. secretary general said they made progress.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grain bins storing corn, wheat, sunflower and soybeans on the grounds of the Agro-Region facility in Boryspil, Ukraine in May.

item.title: Covid Surge in Shanghai Rases Fears of Another Lockdown
item.description: Residents have been alarmed by mixed messages from officials, including advice that they stock up on food and medicine.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:description: A line for Covid testing in Shanghai on Tuesday.

item.title: Far From Kabul, Building a New Life, With Music and Hope
item.description: The students of the Afghanistan National Institute of Music fled after the Taliban seized power. Now they are trying to remake their school, and their dreams, in Portugal.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Isabella Lanave for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zohra was convinced from a young age that she wanted to be a professional musician.

item.title: Brittney Griner heads back to court, caught up in a war far away from home.
item.description: The case of an American sports star at the mercy of Russian justice has rippled across the world amid criticism from Washington that she has been wrongfully detained.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, playing for the Phoenix Mercury, during a W.N.B.A. game with the New York Liberty in 2019.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Gas prices are falling.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gasoline prices have declined 28 days in a row.

item.title: Priests Once Aligned With Russia Come Under Suspicion in Ukraine
item.description: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church was once a dominant force in the country, but now officials suspect that some priests may be collaborating with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Oleksandr Chubko and Vera Mironova
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Priests in the Ukrainian Orthodox Church conducted a Mass in Kyiv, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: In Pictures: Sri Lanka’s Protesters Persist After President’s Departure
item.description: Many digesting the news of Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s exit appeared to relish witnessing a monumental day in the country’s history.
item.dc:creator: Atul Loke and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters took control of the prime minister’s office in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden, Battered at Home, Basks in Unvarnished Praise in Israel
item.description: The U.S. president, on the first day of a trip to the Mideast, received the sort of rapturous welcome he can only dream about in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker, Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: President Biden with his arm around Isaac Herzog, Israel’s president, as he talks with two Holocaust survivors at Yad Vashem in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

item.title: Cardinal Cláudio Hummes, Close Ally of Pope Francis, Dies at 87
item.description: An advocate for the poor, he was a force behind the progressive turn taken by many Latin American Catholics in the 1970s and ’80s.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Cardinal Cláudio Hummes in 2006. He blended doctrinal conservatism with social progressivism and insisted that the Roman Catholic Church lift up people on the margins.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Sri Lanka’s Leader Flees
item.description: Plus President Biden visits Israel, and negotiations continue over Ukraine’s blocked grain.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protestors took control of the prime minister’s office yesterday, as well as the state broadcaster.

item.title: Hawaii, the last state with an indoor mask mandate for public schools, will make masks optional.
item.description: Masks will become optional in Hawaii’s schools when the new academic year starts on Aug. 1, as the state tries for “a more normal classroom experience this fall,” a state health official said.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Desks arranged for social distancing in a classroom at Aikahi Elementary School in Kailua, Hawaii, in 2020. Hawaii kept an indoor mask mandate for public schools in effect throuigh the 2021-2022 school year.

item.title: Studies Probe Adenovirus Link to Childhood Hepatitis Cases
item.description: Two new papers add to the circumstantial evidence that a common childhood virus might be involved in the rare hepatitis cases, but many questions remain.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: M. Wurtz/Biozentrum, University of Basel, via Science Source
item.media:description: A colorized transmission electron micrograph of an adenovirus. Adenoviruses, which usually cause cold- or flulike symptoms, are not typically associated with liver inflammation in healthy children.

item.title: Secret Service Employee Sent Home After Arrest in Israel
item.description: The employee had a “physical encounter,” a spokesman for the agency said, although it did not involve a sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden arrived in Jerusalem on Wednesday. A Secret Service team had preceded him in Israel.

item.title: Brittney Griner and the Limits of American Power
item.description: For Griner, and other Americans held prisoner overseas, the road home may be long, and slow.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Brittney Griner being escorted to a courtroom for a hearing, in Khimki outside Moscow, Russia, last week.

item.title: What Is Yad Vashem, Israel’s Holocaust Memorial?
item.description: President Biden met two survivors on a visit to Israel’s official Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: President Biden laying a wreath in the Hall of Remembrance at Yad Vashem on Wednesday. He also rekindled the eternal flame.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Acting President Has a Complicated Political History
item.description: A prime minister six times over, Ranil Wickremesinghe’s leadership has been equated with Sri Lanka’s economic ambitions as well as its collapse.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe of Sri Lanka at his office in Colombo, the country’s capital, in May.

item.title: Biden Sidesteps Request to Meet Family of Shireen Abu Akleh
item.description: The State Department instead invited Shireen Abu Akleh’s family to Washington, according to a U.S. official and the journalist’s brother.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at the site where Shireen Abu Akleh was killed in the West Bank.

item.title: Biden Adopts ‘No Handshake’ Covid Policy, but Not for Long
item.description: A virus subvariant provided a reason to “reduce contact” before a potentially fraught encounter with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia. The plan quickly slipped away in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Mr. Biden greeted Prime Minister Yair Lapid and President Isaac Herzog with fist bumps.

item.title: The Maldives may not be the Sri Lankan leader’s last stop.
item.description: For deposed leaders, the choice of where to hole up after being ousted can be determined by a number of factors, including historical and political ties between the countries, and, for some, extradition treaties.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: The skyline of Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: Israelis prepare for the traffic snarl of the decade.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: American flags were flown on streets throughout Jerusalem before President Biden’s visit to Israel.

item.title: A Surprisingly Tight Race
item.description: Despite Biden’s low approval ratings, Democrats are roughly tied with Republicans in the midterm polls. We explain why.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Latinos for Trump demonstration in Miami in 2020.

item.title: Biden’s Saudi trip is framed as centering on national security, but oil is the most urgent factor.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Christophe Viseux for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil terminal at the seaport of Ras Tanura in Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Protesters take over the prime minister’s office and state broadcaster.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Skandha Gunasekara
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe’s office on Wednesday.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Protest Movement Began With Candlelight Vigil
item.description: The goals are disparate and there are no clear leaders. The protesters included students and trade unionists, Catholic nuns and Buddhist monks, farmers and middle-class professionals.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: Sri Lanka’s opposition leader Sajith Premadasa, center, acknowledged supporters during a protest calling for the resignation of the president Gotabaya Rajapaksa in Colombo, Sri Lanka, June 30, 2022.

item.title: How Demand for Twigs Is Bringing Down a Rainforest
item.description: In the Congo River Basin, people who collect bundles of wood to make charcoal are playing a surprisingly large role in the deforestation of a region that rivals the Amazon in importance.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Ashley Gilbertson

item.title: In Portugal, Taking a Dive Into Sardines
item.description: The canned fish are having a moment in the food world. A tour of a canning factory in Porto gives an up-close view of a century-old business.
item.dc:creator: Lily Puckett
item.media:credit: Daniel Rodrigues for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Conservas Pinhais factory tour lets visitors look behind the scenes as sardines are canned. Almost all the workers are women and here they prepare the fish to be steamed.

item.title: Can Planting a Trillion New Trees Save the World?
item.description: To fight climate change, companies and nonprofits have been promoting worldwide planting campaigns. Getting to a trillion is easier said than done.
item.dc:creator: Zach St. George
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers hired by Eden Reforestation Projects planting trees in the northern part of Goiás State, Brazil.

item.title: Tear gas fired at protesters outside the prime minister’s office.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara and Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe’s office on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Mideast Trip Fraught With Political Perils
item.description: President Biden is heading to the Mideast with one eye on U.S. strategic goals abroad and another on his political vulnerabilities back home.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden embarked on a visit to the Middle East on Tuesday night.

item.title: Protesters March in Sri Lanka After President Flees Country
item.description: Security forces fired tear gas in an effort to disperse people. Families with young children were among those marching.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sri Lankans lined up Tuesday to get inside the president’s residence, which was taken over by protesters.

item.title: In Divide Over Ukraine, China Stakes a Position Further From U.S.
item.description: Recent statements have underscored the deep chasms in a relationship that is getting worse, as the Biden administration tries to come up with a cohesive China policy.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:description: China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, and U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Bali, Indonesia, last week.

item.title: A Timeline of How the Crisis in Sri Lanka Developed
item.description: In recent months, Sri Lanka has run out of food and fuel, prompting a swelling protest movement. Here’s a timeline of how the situation has unfolded.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: People thronging the prime minister’s residence on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s oil war with the West.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil tanker anchored at docks in Venezuela in 2021. A longtime ally of the Kremlin, Venezuela has had to sharply discount its crude exports as Russia has turned to new buyers for its own oil.

item.title: History Haunts Ukraine’s Undiplomatic Voice in Berlin
item.description: Debate over a Ukrainian nationalist leader’s role in the Holocaust has exposed how views of the past shape European allies’ relationships with Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Andriy Melnyk, second from right, at a World War II commemoration in Berlin in May. As Ukraine’s ambassador to Germany, he became a provocative favorite on the talk show circuit.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Parliament Holds Key to Who Will Lead Next
item.description: The spotlight is now on a parliament that has long frustrated the island nation of 22 million, with lawmakers and political parties engaging in protracted and messy fights over positions of power.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Special Task Force personnel guard near the Parliament building in Colombo, Sri Lanka in May.

item.title: Fake Indian Cricket League Swindles Russian Gamblers
item.description: The bats and balls were real, but not much else was authentic in what officials said was an elaborate scheme to dupe Russian gamblers through hoax games streamed on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: A real Indian Premier League match between the Mumbai Indians and the Chennai Super Kings in Hyderabad, India, in 2019.

item.title: President Rajapaksa arrives in the Maldives.
item.dc:creator: Skandha Gunasekara
item.media:description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka left around 2 a.m. Wednesday Sri Lankan time on an air force plane.

item.title: Why Sri Lankan Protesters Demanded the President’s Resignation.
item.description: For many Sri Lankans, food and fuel became either impossible to find or too expensive to buy.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protests against high prices, power cuts and the Sri Lankan government in Colombo, the capital, in March.

item.title: European Space Agency Cuts Ties With Russia on Its Mars Mission
item.description: Washington and Moscow are continuing to work together on the International Space Station.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Aoes Medialab M.Thiebaut/European Space Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An artist’s rendition of the ESA ExoMars robot on Mars.

item.title: Putin, Looking for Allies, Plans to Meet Leaders of Turkey and Iran
item.description: In his second diplomatic push since Russia invaded Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin will travel to Tehran to build bridges between leaders at odds over Syria, oil and the West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: Wave of Repression Spreads in Iran Against Artists and Dissidents
item.description: Three filmmakers were arrested, as well as a politician and several family members of people killed in anti-government protests.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Mohammad Rasolouf and Mostafa Aleahmad, two filmmakers who were arrested in Iran, in a photograph provided by colleagues.

item.title: Biden Meets With Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador
item.description: The White House meeting between President Biden and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador was intended to help shore up a critical relationship.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Biden met with President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Putin’s Oil War With the West Comes at His Allies’ Expense
item.description: Russia’s use of energy as a weapon in its standoff with the West is redrawing the geopolitical map, but it could strain ties with allies like Iran and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil tanker anchored at docks in Venezuela in 2021.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Extreme Heat Grips China
item.description: Plus the conviction of an ailing Hong Kong activist and President Vladimir Putin’s upcoming trip to Iran.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A woman used a fan during a heat wave in Shanghai on Tuesday.

item.title: C.D.C. Still Unprepared to Respond Quickly to Global Travel Threats, U.S. Audit Finds
item.description: A new report exposes the outdated data collection methods still relied on by the public health agency.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Mohamed Sadek for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York’s LaGuardia Airport on July 2. A new report found that the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s system for gathering data for contact tracing “needs substantial improvement.”

item.title: U.S. Military Says Senior ISIS Leader in Syria Killed in Drone Strike
item.description: The attack was the latest in a series of American operations against ISIS and Al Qaeda in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A crater from a drone strike in Syria on Tuesday. The attack was the latest of several American military operations against ISIS and Al Qaeda in Syria.

item.title: Mo Farah Documentary Puts Spotlight on U.K.’s Hard-line Policy
item.description: Experts hope the running star’s revelations will humanize migrants’ struggles, but they don’t expect policy changes in a country that is trying to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Mo Farah celebrating winning the men’s 10,000-meter final at the 2016 Summer Olympics.

item.title: In a frontline town, the City Council ‘is not working,’ and the few who venture out don’t stray far.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Kamila Hrabchuk
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Siversk, in eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday. The frontline town is still home to about 3,500 residents, including 200 children.

item.title: Putin and Erdogan to Talk in Tehran, Spotlighting Complicated Relationship
item.description: The meetings in Iran also position Turkey as a key mediator between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, which shares the Black Sea coast with both Russia and Ukraine. He has emerged as one of the most active mediators between their leaders.

item.title: Pandemic Remains a Global Health Emergency, W.H.O. Says
item.description: “Covid-19 is nowhere near over,” the agency’s director general declared.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coronavirus vaccination clinic in San Juan, P.R., in May.

item.title: Manchin, Playing to the Home Crowd, Is Fighting Electric Cars to the End
item.description: The West Virginia senator, who holds the swing vote in negotiations for a budget plan, wants to cut incentives. The president and most Senate Democrats say buyer credits are crucial to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Joe Manchin III and other leaders from West Virginia want the federal government to invest billions of dollars to create a “hydrogen hub” in their state.
